alt_statements.statement: I think tech companies should have to explain clearly what data they’re collecting and what they’re doing with it, in words that even kids my age can understand. They shouldn’t be allowed to sell or share our information without asking us (and our parents) first, and they should protect it really carefully so it doesn’t get leaked or misused. If they make money from our data, they should use some of that to make their platforms safer and kinder, not just more addictive or unfair.

As someone who spends a lot of time online tracking bird migrations and using apps on the trail, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to be transparent and honest about what data they collect and how they profit from it. Users should have clear, simple options to opt out of data sharing and to delete their information, not just pages of fine print nobody can realistically parse. I’m not against companies making money, but they shouldn’t treat our personal lives like open season—basic respect, consent, and strong privacy protections ought to be the standard, not an afterthought.

I think tech companies should have to ask people really clearly before they take our information, and explain it in simple words so even kids like me can understand. They shouldn’t be allowed to use or sell our data in sneaky ways, and they should keep it super safe so bad people can’t steal it. Since my parents and church teach me about honesty and treating others fairly, I think companies should follow those same rules when they use our data.

As someone who works with people’s information every day in a library, I think tech companies should treat user data more like we treat patron records: as something private and not to be used without clear, informed consent. They should be upfront and plainspoken about what they collect, how they profit from it, and give users easy, real choices to opt out. There also need to be strong protections so this data isn’t used to manipulate people or discriminate against them, especially kids and vulnerable groups.

As someone who makes a living sifting through evidence and fine print, I think tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data like a serious liability, not a limitless asset. They should be required to explain clearly—without legalese—what they’re collecting, how it’s being used, and who it’s being sold or shared with, and users should have real control to opt out without being punished by a worse product. There also need to be strict legal limits on secondary uses of data (like profiling for insurance, employment, or credit) and meaningful penalties when companies are deceptive or negligent with people’s information. In a world where data can quietly shape people’s financial and personal lives, basic transparency and accountability shouldn’t be optional or buried in a 40-page terms-of-service.

As someone who works in national security, I understand the value of data, but I also know how dangerous it can be when it’s misused or not properly safeguarded. They should collect only what’s truly necessary, be completely transparent about how it’s used and monetized, and give people real, easy-to-use options to opt out. Profit shouldn’t come at the expense of basic dignity and autonomy, and there ought to be strong regulations—like HIPAA for health info—that protect all of us online, not just the tech-savvy.

As someone who works hard every day to support my family, I think tech companies should be straight-up and honest about what they’re doing with our data, and get real consent instead of hiding things in fine print. If they’re making money off our information, they should protect it like it’s their own, and some of that profit should go back into the communities they’re taking it from—through better services, privacy protections, or even direct benefits.

As someone who works with financial records every day, I think tech companies should be held to at least the same standard of accuracy, transparency, and accountability that we expect in accounting. If they’re going to collect and profit from our data, they should be required by law to clearly explain what they’re collecting, get real consent (not buried in legalese), minimize what they store, and be fully liable when they misuse it or fail to protect it. Our data shouldn’t be treated as a free-for-all commodity just because we clicked “I agree”; people’s privacy and dignity need to come before ad revenue.

If tech companies are going to collect and profit off our data, they should have to spell out in plain English exactly what they’re taking, what they’re doing with it, and give us a real choice to opt out. I work hard for what I earn and live pretty simple, so I don’t like the idea of big companies quietly making money off my personal information without strict rules, strong protections against abuse, and serious penalties when they cross the line.

I don’t really understand computers yet, but my mom uses her phone a lot and talks about how apps shouldn’t be sneaky. They should keep our information safe so bad people can’t get it and so my family doesn’t have to worry about who’s watching what we do.

I think if a company wants my data, they should ask in words kids and grown-ups can both understand, not tiny hard-to-read stuff. They should only take what they really need for the game or app to work and keep it super safe so no bad people can get it. If they make money from my data, they should tell my parents exactly how and give us choices to say yes or no.

As a conservative and a business manager, I understand companies need to make money, but they also have a duty to be straight with people about what data they collect and how they use it. Tech companies should be required to get clear, informed consent, protect that data like it was their own family’s, and be fully accountable when they misuse or lose it. I don’t want heavy-handed government control, but I do think we need basic rules of the road so regular folks aren’t taken advantage of by fine print and shady practices.

As someone who serves in the military and takes security and discipline seriously, I believe tech companies have a duty to treat user data with the same level of protection we expect for sensitive information in uniform. They should collect only what’s necessary, be completely transparent about how it’s used and monetized, and give users straightforward control over their own data. When national security or public safety might be affected, there should be clear legal standards and oversight—not secret deals or vague policies. In my view, profit should never come before protecting individuals and families from exploitation, surveillance abuse, or data breaches.

As someone who spends a lot of time thinking about how models behave under different assumptions, I think tech companies have an obligation to treat user data with the same rigor and care we apply to human-subjects research in hospitals: explicit informed consent, clear limits on use, and strict anonymization. Monetizing data is not inherently wrong, but it has to be transparent, opt-in by default, and subject to strong regulation so that individuals aren’t turned into opaque “inputs” whose privacy, autonomy, and political agency can be silently optimized away.

If tech companies are going to collect and profit off our data, they should at least be completely transparent and make it easy to opt out, not bury everything in 20 pages of legal jargon. I might not be a tech expert, but I know that if I treated customers’ info at my job the way some companies do online, I’d be fired on the spot.

As someone who grew up long before smartphones and social media, I believe tech companies have a moral duty to be honest and straightforward about what data they collect and how they profit from it. These companies make a lot of money from our information, so they should be held accountable—by law if necessary—when they misuse it or fail to protect it. Basic respect for privacy and human dignity shouldn’t be optional in a civilized, Christian society.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see how much tech has changed our lives, I believe companies have a moral duty to treat our data with the same care they’d want for their own families. They should collect only what’s truly necessary, clearly explain what they’re doing in plain language, and never sell or share data in ways that exploit people—especially the vulnerable, like the elderly and disabled. If they profit from our information, they should be held legally accountable when that trust is broken. And just as I care about protecting the environment for future generations, I think we need strong, lasting privacy protections so our digital lives aren’t strip-mined for profit.

Given how much of our lives now exist online, tech companies have a serious responsibility to treat user data like a public health and environmental resource—something to be protected, not exploited. Just as we regulate pollution and toxic exposures, we need strict rules and independent oversight to prevent data abuses that can harm privacy, democracy, and vulnerable communities.

As someone who works in tech and understands how valuable data is, I think companies have a responsibility to be radically transparent about what they’re collecting, why, and how they’re monetizing it—no dark patterns, no buried fine print. From both a moral and democratic standpoint, we can’t treat people’s data as an unlimited resource to exploit; there should be strict limits on data sharing, strong security requirements, and real accountability when companies misuse or fail to safeguard personal information.

As someone who works hard to earn every dollar and depends on trust in my own business, I think tech companies should have the same respect for people’s data that I have for my clients’ money and safety on a job site. As someone who works every day to protect and support vulnerable kids, I think tech companies should treat user data—especially children’s data—with the same level of care we give to student records: clear consent, strict limits on what’s collected, and full transparency about how it’s used and who profits. Tech firms should be legally and ethically accountable, with simple, accessible privacy controls instead of burying users in confusing fine print.

Tech companies have a moral responsibility to be upfront and honest about what data they collect, how they use it, and to get clear consent instead of hiding things in long, confusing policies. There need to be firm rules and real penalties to prevent abuse, because ordinary folks shouldn’t have to be tech experts just to protect their privacy.

I don’t really understand all the tech stuff, but I know people should be honest and not take things without asking. My parents should be able to decide what happens with my data, and the companies should keep it safe like a secret they’re not allowed to break.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how sensitive personal information can be, I believe tech companies have a serious moral obligation to treat user data more like medical records: private by default, transparently handled, and never exploited without clear, informed consent. They shouldn’t be allowed to hide behind long, confusing terms of service—people deserve to know exactly what is being collected, how it’s being used, and to have real control over opting in or out. Tech profits shouldn’t come at the expense of human dignity, safety, or fairness, and strong regulations are needed to make sure companies respect those boundaries.

As someone who works face-to-face with customers every day, I believe tech companies should treat user data with the same respect and honesty I owe the people who walk into my store. With the kind of money these companies make, they have no excuse not to invest in strong security and privacy protections, especially for vulnerable communities like immigrants and working families. At the end of the day, people are not products, and the law should hold big tech accountable when they forget that.

I think tech companies should have to ask people very clearly before they take our information, kind of like asking permission before borrowing a toy. Tech companies shouldn’t be allowed to treat people’s data like a free-for-all commodity. I’d rather see strong, common-sense regulations that protect privacy and punish abuse than let big tech quietly track every move we make just to squeeze out more ad dollars.

As someone who spends a lot of time thinking about ethics and evidence, I believe tech companies have a fundamental responsibility to treat user data less like a commodity and more like a form of personal autonomy. Moreover, when individuals’ data fuels highly profitable AI and advertising systems, there should be meaningful transparency and avenues for users to opt out or share in the value created from their information.

As someone who loves tech and depends on devices—like my hearing aid and all the apps I use—I get that data is what keeps a lot of this stuff running and improving. As someone who spent a career working on power lines, I believe tech companies should treat user data like we treat electricity: powerful, dangerous if mishandled, and never to be used without clear permission and safeguards. They ought to be upfront in plain language about what they collect, how they profit from it, and give people real choices to opt out without losing basic services. If they can’t secure the data and use it responsibly, they shouldn’t be collecting it in the first place.

If these tech companies are going to collect and make money off our data, they ought to be straight with us about what they’re taking, who they’re selling it to, and give us a real choice to opt out without jumping through hoops.
